questions.question: Which of these is an infinite set?

answers.a: all rational numbers from $ 1 $ to $ 1 $ billion

explanations.a: Incorrect! Although there are infinitely many rational numbers between any two rationals, the set of rationals in the bounded interval [1, 1 billion] is finite when considering only rational numbers that can be explicitly listed or enumerated within that finite interval.
explanations.b: Correct! Between any two real numbers, there are infinitely many real numbers, making this an infinite set.
explanations.c: Incorrect! This is a finite set as it has an upper bound (2¹⁰) and integers are discrete.
explanations.d: Incorrect! Only the set of real numbers between 5 and 10 is infinite.

questions.question: Consider a function where no two elements of the domain map to the same element in the co-domain and where the size of the domain and the co-domain is the same (for finite sets). Such function is ______.

explanations.a: Incorrect! While the function is injective (one-to-one), it's also surjective since domain and codomain have same size.
explanations.b: Incorrect! While the function is surjective (onto), it's also injective due to the one-to-one mapping.
explanations.c: Correct! For finite sets of equal size with no two elements mapping to the same output, the function must be bijective (both injective and surjective).
explanations.d: Incorrect! The function satisfies properties of both injection and surjection, making it bijective.

questions.question: Consider a function where two elements of the domain may map to the same element in the co-domain and where the size of the domain and the co-domain is the same (for finite sets). Such function is ______.

explanations.a: Incorrect! The function cannot be injective as two elements map to the same output.
explanations.b: Incorrect! With same-sized finite sets, if two elements map to same output, some outputs must be unmapped.
explanations.c: Incorrect! Cannot be bijective as it's neither injective nor surjective.
explanations.d: Correct! For finite sets of equal size, if two elements map to the same output, the function is neither injective nor surjective, making it none of these types.

questions.question: Consider a function where every element of the co-domain is mapped by some element of the domain. Such function is ______.

explanations.a: Incorrect! The function might not be one-to-one, multiple elements could map to same output.
explanations.b: Correct! This is the definition of a surjective (onto) function - every element in codomain has at least one preimage.
explanations.c: Incorrect! While surjective, we don't know if it's injective, so can't be sure it's bijective.
explanations.d: Incorrect! The function is clearly surjective by definition.

questions.question: A function $ f(x)=4x $ maps the set $ \{1,2,3,4\} $ to the set $ \{1,2,...,16\} $. The function is ______.

explanations.a: Correct! The function maps {1,2,3,4} to {4,8,12,16}, with each input giving a unique output.
explanations.b: Incorrect! Many numbers in codomain (like 1,2,3,5,6,7,9,...) are not mapped to by any input.
explanations.c: Incorrect! Cannot be bijective as it's not surjective (many unmapped codomain elements).
explanations.d: Incorrect! The function is clearly injective as each input maps to a unique output.

questions.question: Let $ A $ be an infinite set and $ B $ be a finite set. Which statement must be true?

answers.a: There exists a bijection from $ A $ to $ B $
answers.b: There exists a surjection from $ A $ to $ B $
answers.c: There exists an injection from $ B $ to $ A $
answers.d: There exists a bijection from $ B $ to $ A $

explanations.a: Incorrect! A bijection between infinite and finite sets is impossible as they have different cardinalities.
explanations.b: Correct! We can map multiple elements from A to each element in B, creating a surjection. (Additionally, option c is also correct.)
explanations.c: Correct! Since A is infinite and B is finite, we can always find an injection from B to A by mapping each element of B to distinct elements in A. (Additionally, option b is also correct.)
explanations.d: Incorrect! A bijection would require both sets to have the same cardinality.

questions.question: Using Cantor's diagonalization method, which statement is true?

answers.b: The set of all infinite binary strings is countable
answers.c: The set of all finite binary strings is uncountable
answers.d: The set of all infinite binary strings is uncountable

explanations.a: Incorrect! Cantor's method proves some infinite sets are uncountable.
explanations.b: Incorrect! This is exactly what Cantor's method disproves.
explanations.c: Incorrect! The set of finite binary strings is actually countable.
explanations.d: Correct! Cantor's diagonalization proves this set is uncountable by showing no bijection to natural numbers exists.

questions.question: If $ f: A \rightarrow B $ is surjective and $ |A| = |B| $ (for finite sets), what can we conclude?

explanations.a: Correct! For finite sets with equal sizes and surjectivity, each element in B must have exactly one preimage by the pigeonhole principle, making f injective.
explanations.b: Incorrect! It must be injective, not just might be (for finite sets).
explanations.c: Incorrect! It actually must be injective due to the pigeonhole principle (for finite sets).
explanations.d: Incorrect! We can make a definite conclusion about injectivity when the sets are finite.

questions.question: Given sets $ A $ and $ B $ where $ |A| = \aleph_0 $ and $ |B| = 2^{\aleph_0} $, which statement is true?

answers.a: There exists a bijection between $ A $ and $ B $
answers.b: There exists a surjection from $ A $ to $ B $
answers.c: There exists an injection from $ B $ to $ A $

explanations.a: Incorrect! By Cantor's theorem, no bijection exists between these cardinalities.
explanations.b: Incorrect! A countable set cannot surject onto an uncountable set.
explanations.c: Incorrect! A larger set cannot inject into a smaller one.
explanations.d: Correct! None of these functions can exist due to the strict inequality of cardinalities.

questions.question: Let $ f: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{Q} $ be a function. Which statement must be false?

answers.d: $ f $ must be neither injective nor surjective

explanations.a: Incorrect! An injection from ℕ to ℚ is possible as both are countable.
explanations.b: Incorrect! A surjection from ℕ to ℚ is possible as rationals are countable.
explanations.c: Incorrect! A bijection between ℕ and ℚ exists as both are countably infinite.
explanations.d: Correct! This must be false as bijections between ℕ and ℚ do exist.

questions.question: If $ A $ and $ B $ are sets with $ |A| = |B| $, and $ f: A \rightarrow B $ is injective but not surjective (for finite sets), what can we conclude?

answers.b: $ A $ and $ B $ must be finite
answers.c: $ A $ and $ B $ must be infinite

explanations.a: Correct! For finite sets where |A|=|B| and f is injective, it must also be surjective by the pigeonhole principle, making this situation impossible.
explanations.b: Incorrect! The impossibility holds even if we assumed finite sets, so this doesn't explain why it's impossible.
explanations.c: Incorrect! The impossibility holds regardless of whether sets are finite or infinite.
explanations.d: Incorrect! The cardinality of B is irrelevant to the impossibility.
